top_comment.text:
#Poetry....  By +Michael Montoya 

Your Soul Mate...

Together...  forever
what once was.. will be again..
the sands of time flow eternal..
 View the stars.. they were once ours
 as we stared ...holding each other
knowing we were immortal.. in our love
 and yet we would pass
 into stardust once again...
 For time escapes none.. but Love..
knows no boundaries of time and distance...
 I have carried your heart...
 across the many spheres of  Loves ethereal legends..
 Zeus and Ganymede.. Apollo and Hyacinthus...
 Romeo and Juliet...
Yes... all  are still  waiting for their own time
 to once again be together..  Now
 We.. will be one star in the sky ..
looked upon as Lovers...across the Universe
  keep hope in their hearts..
that they will soon be
One Again... My Love..
My Soul Mate..

Written by Michael Montoya.. 11/9/2014 at11:50 AM.﻿

top_comment.text:
I have lucid dreams several times a week. I would rather not have them 
though. It have come to the point where I have problems separating dreams 
from reality and I often mix them up wich have made me extremely confused 
about life and everything! I constantly walk around doing reality checks to 
see if I am awake or dreaming. It's pretty scary because what happens if I 
think that I'm only dreaming when I'm actually awake? I could jump off a 
cliff or kill someone and believe that everything will go back to normal 
again when I wake up... =/ And yes I do see a therapist... lol﻿
top_comment.author: Aerox ⁣

comments.text:
dude something is wrong in your brain if you find it hard to realize you 
are awake
comments.author: Lucid Dream

comments.text:
What I meant is that you might not have lucid dreamed at all or where just 
trolling with hypothetical pseudo-science. When you dream there is an 
hormone that is segregated that paralyses you, I believe Adrenalyn or 
something is an antagonist of it so that you can wake up ready to 
flee/fight if you sense any danger, loud noises, etc... this hormone is 
there so that you don't jump of a cliff or facepalm yourself out of the 
bed, etc, unless you are a sleep walker which are persons with problems 
syntetizing this hormone, nothing is going to happen, if you honestly have 
a hard time destinguishing a dream from reality that has nothing to do with 
lucid dreaming and you might have some other serious condition that you 
should check. The whole point of it being a lucid dreaming is that you 
clearly know you are dreaming trough gaining conscious during a dream.

I've recently started smoking weed for medical purposes, and I find it

week. I'm not inducing drug use without a doctors prescription!

+Adam Eriksson Idk if this helps but I sometimes feel im not in reality or 
I feel the need to reach out and grab the things infront of me to make sure 
theyre real sort of thing while I am dealing with unresolved/repressed 
trauma. We may be dealing with two different things but I found it was at 
its worse when I used things that altered my state of mind (weed mostly) 
and stopping that helped a lot. But dealing with it helped the most, and Im 
sure if i lucid dreamed constantly Id be twice as bad

+Adam Eriksson I had the exact same problem. There was one point that I 
lucid dream too often that I couldnt differentiate some of the stuff that I 
dreamed about from my reality. It sure was really confusing. On many 
occasions I tried to wake up from my dream, only to find out that I was 
still dreaming, and after several tries I woke up eventually, but kept 
wondering if i was still dreaming for like 10 mins. Not sure why but my 
lucid dreams just stopped for a few months now and I dont have the problem 
anymore.
comments.author: kamkuytmit

comments.text:
+Rick Janssen No they just happens. I remember having exactly the same 
dream as you when I was a kid! :O I dreamed that I was sleeping and tried 
to wake up, but when I woke up I wasn't in my bed. Then I realized I was 
still dreaming and tried to wake up again, but I just kept waking up at 
different places all the time until I was finally back in my own bed in the 
real world. Scary as hell :S I remember screaming on my mom in my dream and 
asking her where I was and if she could shake me or throw water on me.
comments.author: Aerox ⁣

comments.text:
Adam, did you teach yourself to have lucid dreams? Or do they just happen 
naturally?

I recently had a dream in which I realized I was dreaming. But as soon as I 
realized I immediately woke up. But at that moment I didn't know I was 
still dreaming... I then actually woke up and realized I just had a dream 
inside a dream in which I realized I was dreaming... Dreams are 
fascinating!
comments.author: Rick Janssen

comments.text:
to anybody responding, if you have trouble differentiating dreams from

sleep study performed on you.

a dream I started to wake up, then in the dream I remembered a technique of 
rubbing your hands together, as if youre cold... I consentrated only on my 
hands, and at first nothing happened, I didn't feel the warmth of the 
rubbing, which is such a strange experience, but after a few seconds a heat 
wave struck my arms, and I was back in the dream. Unfortunately I forgot I

comments.author: The Heretic

comments.text:
+Niosus Thanks, these reality checks are a nice addition to my repertoir. 
Another good one is: Recalling how you got into this situation; Not always 
that straight forward or clear in a dream.

+Cat the Turtle It is only too much work if you don't want it enough or are 
not interested in it technically.
I had a lucid dream only after 3 days of constantly checking and really 
questioning myself wether if I was in a dream or not. It wasn't even a 
habit yet that I brought with me into my dream. There is not necessarily a 
need for a dream diary and all that laborious stuff. I don't even think 
reality checks are needed but they are definetly worth their 
simplicity-usefulness-ratio. It's all in your head man, willpower is the 
only criterion.
comments.author: enginowich

comments.text:
+The Cake is not a Vlog I'm usually very long winded. This is not only The 
Internets, it is The YouTubes. Not a place where sane people should get too 
bogged down, in my opinion. I do enjoy the English language very much, 
since early childhood. I started reading a lot in English around age 13, 
and am considered fluent by my 'Murican wife, according to her, these days. 
So, I basically agree... but not in this specific environment, it seems... 
;)
comments.author: Maxander2001

comments.text:
Not in mine.  This is something people really need to learn about 
communication.  Just because you understand something, it does not mean 
others will.

English is a beautifully complex language, with such a massive array of 
nuance.  Words, phrases, ideas and concepts that just do not exist anywhere 
else.  To cheapen that by resorting to such vagaries as "welcome to the 
internet" does that a disservice.  Do not be afraid of the language. 
 Embrace it wholeheartedly
comments.author: The Cake is not a Vlog

comments.author: Niosus

comments.text:
It's okay, I don't either. It helps me to realize it's called, "Big think," 
as opposed to, "Big Just Believe What I'm Saying, Okay?!" The things he 
covers are often ideas brought from the leading edges of science. These are 
things to consider, to research, to discuss, not to blindly accept. So, 
it's damned good your "fact checker" kicks in and calls 'BS' - but as long 
as we're also appreciating the ideas for what they are, I think they hold 
significant value.

---- gets on soapbox -----
That's always been a problem with the thinking of the masses. They/we've 
always wanted people to do our thinking for us and tell us the 'correct' 
answer. It works wonderfully with much of our lives, like when our car 
isn't starting, it's nice to have an expert around to tell us the correct 
answer regarding getting it started again.

However, when considering the mysteries of the human mind and the universe 
at large (or very small), we tend to look for the same thing, when what we 
should realize is there is no "cosmic mechanic" that knows all. There are 
only a few people who have some very interesting ideas about the nature of 
the unknown, and that they are guides or springboards for our own thinking 
and not answer givers. It's in situations like these that we need to use 
our amazing brains to add to the search for answers, instead of wasting our 
great potential and waiting for the answers to arrive.
---- falls off soapbox ----
comments.author: Alex Pope

that plus probably about 20 because that's the roughly amount of up-votes 
on comments arguing against yours. That's also only counting the amount of 
people who bother to vote on comments. Lets assume it's a 50/50 split (a 
conservative estimate in my opinion). So based on this estimate, you've 
re-enforced the bias of at least 50 people.

of opinion without evidence, and even you yourself have come back and said 
it was illogical based on THIS video.

your comment, and came to the conclusion that the content of this video is 
bunk, a belief they will continue to hold. All purely based on EMOTION and

comments.author: elhaupto

comments.text:
+elhaupto  oh you're majoring in bio? I'm working on a Master's in 
psychology (psychology is about 50% biology, 50% behavior and 
consciousness) and nothing he said was wrong. He used peer reviewed 
studies, which I actually read about, 
http://journals.humankinetics.com/tsp-back-issues/tspvolume24issue2june/practicingamotortaskinaluciddreamenhancessubsequentperformanceapilotstudy
.
The prefrontal cortex is the executive center of the brain. It's where our 
higher order thinking happens. It's shut down when dreaming. In fact, the 
reason why teenagers do dumb things is because their prefrontal cortex 
isn't fully developed and "online" during the teen years. People with ADHD 
have problems with dopamine reception in the prefrontal cortex, which is 
why stimulants flood the synaptic centers with dopamine. Our bodies are 
paralyzed in REM sleep, which is the state of sleep dreaming happens in. 
REM sleep is most like being awake. It's the lightest sleep. When we wake 
from REM, we are less groggy than if we wake from stage 3/4 sleep. The 
Freudian view of dreams is not considered scientific because it can't be 
reproduced experimentally. At best, the Freudian view of dreams can be 
considered philosophy. Now tell me where I'm wrong. And if you want to 
consider yourself a good scientist, you wouldn't complain about having to 
put things in lay terms. I know you think you're a scientist, but you're 
not yet. A good scientist, like Kaku, is able to explain scientific 
concepts to non scientists. Nothing he said in this video is false, I have 
a B.A. telling you he's right.
comments.author: Vic Vinegar

top_comment.text:
+Big Think I have an interesting story to share with you about my lucid 
dreaming (small wall of text below)...

Around the time I was 20 years old (about 4.5 years ago), I conducted an 
experiment to see if I could use my lucid dreaming to view into my past 
memories and possibly re-live them instead of just having a dream, then 
controlling it halfway in. Most of my normal dreams seemed to be centered 
around my emotions and how I truly felt about things going on in my current 
life, so I had a good feeling my memories were connected to strong 
emotions. Anyway, it took about 3 nights to pull off, but I did it. 
However, there was a catch...

In the dream, I put myself in a long, white hallway with a door at the end, 
much like the 2nd Matrix movie in the Keymaker scene, but I understood 
there were memories behind this door. So I walked to the door, grabbed the 
doorknob, and only cracked the door open wide enough to peak in...and...I 
relived EVERY single thing I've ever regretted since I was 3 years 
old...even the smallest things like forgetting to vacuum the living room 
before my parents got home or something. I can't exactly recall the 
memories I saw anymore. I assume it's stored away in my subconscious mind. 
But the memories went backwards in time in chronological order and they 
stopped when I was 3 years old, and then repeated. You can only imagine 
just how much I witnessed if a 3 year old had something to regret lol.

The memories were so intense that it woke me up from my sleep, and I could 
still see these memories flashing before my eyes one after another in the 
darkness of my room for about 10-15 seconds, as they slowly faded away. The 
whole ordeal seemed to only last 20 seconds including when I woke up from 
the dream. That means I was seeing multiple memories every second, but I 
could see them all as clear as a night sky in Texas.

So, I haven't tried to do it again since then. Not only did I have a 
"laundry list" of factors I had to overcome the first time but if I can't 
control which "door" I'm going to be peaking into next time, then I'm 
afraid to even try it again. 

And I can't stress enough how intense this dream was though. I wish I 
possessed the proper literary skills to describe just how intense it was 
but I'll try to sum it up: It's similar to how I feel on roller coasters 
and I'm afraid of heights. That dream really messed up my mood for a full 
24 hours and it left me with a pretty good headache....and I only opened my 
"door of regrets". Just imagine if it were my "door of sorrows".﻿
top_comment.author: WuKingdom1

comments.text:

looking for my record, but the record keeper was away.  I insisted to see 
him and they told me he was inside a column next to where I was standing, 
outside from the record archives.  I went straight to the column and opened 
a small door.  He was a bat, hanging next to the small door.  When he saw 
the light he sent me a striking look, he was so angry and disturbed!
I asked a few persons and a psicologist and the answer was that I was not 
ready yet to know what was written in my record, meaning I was not ready 
yet to know all about certain aspects of my life.  When the moment comes, 
then we should do it through meditation guided by an expert.  This is what 
I learned.  I hope it is useful.

comments.text:
+str8todamoney  I'm not exactly sure what you're trying to get at there 
but, I think I should explain why I've said what I have. "Areas" or "parts" 
of the brain "light up" under the scanner when an individual does certain 
things. A cool fact about motion or action is moving your hand, seeing 
someone else's hand move or imaging your hand move will all produce similar 
"activation" in the brain, under the scanner. Dreaming is no different. So 
yes, maybe in the participants dream he did as he was instructed. But maybe 
he was simply walking or doing some other type of motion involving the 
hand. This would also cause these same brain areas to light up. The Sam 
Harris talk, is about one's own experience in conjunction with with 
objective measures.  & How the two are inseparable. I agree with this. I 
mean, look at most social sciences,  subjective coherence often leads to 
some objective conclusion. The key thing here is that such coherence leads 
to narrowing  down the reason behind a given phenomenon.  Now, going back 
to our original brain activation experiment & this lucid dreaming talk, the 
problem isn't necessarily with anecdotal evidence or subjective experience. 
The problem is in placing value on such a thing while lacking the objective 
measure to back it.
comments.author: Yoel Sanchez

comments.text:

to learn why anecdotal evidence shouldn't be discarded when it comes to 
psychology.

comments.text:

clear. Lucid dreaming is being aware that you are dreaming which has 
happened to me & that isn't what I'm arguing. Now, what Mr. Kaku states in 
this talk is they gave someone instructions to do a task before this person 
went to sleep. Said person fell asleep and bam you see brain activation 
that shows the motor cortex areas associated with hand movement. THIS IN NO 
WAY proves that the individual while asleep, while dreaming carried out the 
instructions given. NOW, that, if it WERE the case would be scientifically 
confirming lucid dreaming. Results through experimentation & antidotal 
evidence are two different things. I myself can give antidotal evidence 
supporting lucid dreaming but in no way does that confirm it.

comments.text:
My hypothesis is that a dream is a side effect of REM sleep. When in REM, 
parts of our brain are active and other parts aren't. When those parts of 
our brain are active, they do their normal job. When your fact checking 
part of the brain is turned off, then the resulting effect will be a 
bizarre experience, aka dream. But I don't think that dreams are like an 
evolutionary adaptation like many of our other behaviors and things are. 
They're just a side effect of your brain cleaning itself out. Sleep is 
basically memory consolidation. Sleep isn't to conserve energy because you 
burn about the same amount of calories asleep as awake, I think of it like 
defragmenting a hard drive and putting memories in the right spot on the 
hard drive. I only have a B.A. in psychology but I am working on a master's 
just to let you know I'm not just making this up out of thin air.
comments.author: Vic Vinegar

comments.text:
'fact-checker' aka the frontal cortex, the frontal cortex turns off when 
you're in REM sleep.

Tesla should not have thought about wireless communications after AC 
electricity or bothered to think about aerodynamics and cars (especially

philosophy, play Violin or do math on his free time.

comments.author: magzire

comments.text:
It didn't really make it up. Your mind used bits and pieces of things 
you've seen to produce that image. Perhaps from Star Wars or Star Trek. The 
imagery of your dreams can only come from what you have seen. If you have 
never seen an airplane, you will never dream of an airplane. That's why 
blind people dream of sounds and touch.

comments.author: DjNotNice88

top_comment.text:
From what I can remember, my first lucid dream was around age 11. I can 
remember this particular dream because it was one of the most terrifying 
experiences of my childhood. I was in my room sleeping and all of a sudden 
for whatever reason, I had woken up but i was paralyze at the same time, I 
was so terrified about not being able to open my eyes or arms that I had no 
idea what was going on, all i could think of was "I need some help but i 
can't scream or move, so maybe if I breathe harder my mom would somehow 
notice". She didn't. While in that state, my hearing had become super 
sensitive, I was able to listen to things that would normally go unnoticed, 
like the static white noise my stereo would emit. But because of my 
heighten sensitivity of hearing and not knowing what the hell I was 
experiencing, it had induced one the most vivid nightmares I've ever had. A 
couple of years ago I found out that what I had experience was a thing, 
that there is an actual term for it"lucid dreaming", and that it's not only 
possible to have a lucid dream but to control it. The last one I had was 
almost a year ago, but unlike my first, I was ready and in control.﻿
top_comment.author: Roger Meza

comments.text: That's not a lucid dream, that's sleep paralysis.
comments.author: Steven Edelmann

comments.text:
That basically describes the experience I first had when i was about 12, it 
was absolutely terrifying and will never forget that heightened sense of 
pure fear. iv probably had about 100 over the past 20 years but nothing 
compares to that first time.

captions.text:
There’s a whole lore about dreaming. In
fact, Sigmund Freud wrote a book called The

Interpretation of Dreams which many people
think is the foundation of psychoanalysis.

Well scientists now have looked at Freudian
psychology and the brain using all these modern

techniques. And first of all we realize that
perhaps Sigmund Freud wasn’t totally wrong.

There are many textbooks which simply dismiss
Freudian psychology calling it nuts. That

is nothing but the sexual fantasies of a repressed
Venetian scientist of the last century. But

now we realize there’s more to it. First
of all the unconscious mind. We can actually

see the brain in motion and we realize that
much of the activity is totally unconscious.
Just like what Freud predicted.

And Freud also said there is the ego, the
id and the superego, that we are in a constant

battle with our desires and our conscious.
And we see that now with brain scans. The

ego is basically your prefrontal cortex. That
is who you are. When you wonder where am I

anyway. Well, you’re right there. You are
sitting right behind your forehead. And then

your desires. We see the pleasure center right
there at the center of the brain. That is

the libido. We see where the pleasure center
is located. And then your conscience is right

behind your eyes. The orbital frontal cortex
right behind your eyes is where your conscience
is. And so we actually see that in motion.

If you were to see a chocolate cake you would
see these three parts of the brain going zippity

back and forth like a ping pong ball because
you’re constantly debating the pleasure

of eating a chocolate cake versus how fat
you’re gonna become and all the sugar and

the calories that you don’t really need.
So we see the beginnings of Freudian psychology

coming out of brain scans. And now dreams.
Freud had a whole collection of interpretation

of dreams. Scientists have looked at and said,
“Nonsense.” Now we understand the physiology

of the dreaming process. And we realize that
it comes at the back of the brain, the very

primitive part of the brain and that certain
parts of the brain are shut off when you dream.

First of all your prefrontal cortex is basically
shut off, it’s quiet. Your orbital frontal

cortex that is your conscience is also shut
off. But that part of the brain is your fact

checker. The part of the brain that said,
“Hmmm, that’s not right. Something’s

wrong” is right behind your eyes. That’s
shut off.

What is active when you dream is your amygdala.
Now what does your amygdala govern? Fear and

emotions. And so right then you know that
when you dream the active part of the brain

is not the fact checker, not the rational
brain – it’s the emotional brain, the

fearful brain that is active when you dream.
And then there’s some superstition called

lucid dreaming where you can actually control
the direction of the dream. Well that superstition

last year became science fact. At the Max
Planck Institute in Germany they were able

to show once and for all that lucid dreaming
is testable, reproducible – it is real.

And here’s how they did it. They took a
person who was about to go to sleep and told

them that when you dream clench your right
fist and then clench your left fist. Now when

you dream you are paralyzed. You cannot move
when you dream.

Otherwise we’d be able to carry out all
sorts of horrible things and destroy ourselves.

So we are paralyzed when we dream. But when
this person went into a dream state you can

clearly see that the brain initiated orders
to clench your right fist and your left fist.

In other words, he was conscious while he
was dreaming. There are many Buddhist texts,

many texts hundreds of years old that give
you the outlines of how to control dreams.

Lucid dreaming. We now know that it’s not
hogwash that you can actually do this. You

can actually direct the course of your dream.
And then one day we may be able to brain scan

the brain as you dream and put it on a screen.
In which case somebody will be able to see

you dream and know the direction of the dream
and you are conscious of the process. In other

words, the movie Inception is not totally
hogwash.

title: Michio Kaku on the Science of Dreams
